Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Rise and Fall of Galapagos Seamounts
Award.AbstractNarration: The Galapagos Islands are unique in their construction. The islands sit on a laterally extensive platform consisting of thick layered lava flows and intrusions that rises 3 kilometers above the surrounding seafloor. Sitting on this platform and peeking out of the water are major volcanic islands that form the basis of Darwin's treatise on the Origin of Species. Interestingly enough, the islands only comprise about 5 % of the volume of the Galapagos platform, which is thought to have originated by melting of the mantle and oceanic lithosphere via a thermal plume originating deep in the mantle. With the exception subaerially exposed parts of the volcanic islands, much of the Galapagos platform remains unsampled and unstudied. A recent oceanographic expedition to the Galapagos, funded by the Dalio Foundation and the Ocean Exploration Trust, mapped part of the platform between some of the major islands and discovered 70 previously unknown submerged volcanic edifices that appear to sport wave-cut erosional features on their surface, indicating that, once, parts of them were exposed above sea level. Over 150 rock samples were collected on the expedition, with hopes that their geochemistry would help to unravel the relationships between the plume source of magma and the chemistry of the volcanoes themselves. This research project will analyze these samples and provide more sophisticated processing of the bathymetric and other geophysical data that was collected on the recent cruise to the Galapagos in hopes of better understanding the recent volcanic history and the rise and fall of the platform with relation to sea level. Using cosmogenic isotopes and the He that is released during radioactive decay, it is hoped that the vertical movement of the small submerged volcanic features displaying subaerial erosional features can be dated and related to sea level, thermal upwelling due to plume resurgence, and platform subsidence over time. Hypotheses to be tested include examining whether the 70 small Galapagos seamounts each represent their own tapping into the mantle upwelling with magmatic systems that are distinct from the adjacent volcanic islands and each other. This will be tested by analyzing samples from the seamounts for major and trace elements, radiogenic isotopes of Sr, Nd, U, and Pb, and noble gases. These data will be used to look for geochemical similarities and differences. Coupled with this magma source study will be a refinement of the collected seafloor topography to examine relationships between seamounts and their geomorphic features and to identify additional signs of emergence from the ocean, which may reveal information about sea level changes over time. Broader impacts of the work include providing critical site characterization for the Galapagos Marine Research, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Because the submerged volcanic edifices are hotspots of marine life and biodiversity, this work also provides important input into the development of Galapagos protected biological site characterization. Additional impacts include support of an early career faculty member whose gender is under-represented in the sciences and who is employed at an institution in Idaho, an EPSCoR state (i.e., a state that does not receive significant federal funding); significant student training; and outreach to transmit the excitement and wonder of marine geology research to the public. Results of the geophysical and submarine topographic studies will be used by the Ecuadorian government to assess potential tsunami hazards from Galapagos volcanic structures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study focused on two major questions of island evolution in the Galápagos: (1) what is the relationship between the subaerial islands, submarine seamounts, and the deeper magmatic source and (2) what is the history of island vertical motions. Both questions have faced considerable challenges due to scarcity of data from the submarine system. Attempts to understand magmatism the Galápagos have been limited by geochemical datasets that are restricted to the widely spaced islands, resulting in inconclusive or skewed maps of compositional variability. Further, the lack of coral reefs in the Galapagos, which is the primary tool for reconstructing paleo-sea-level in Hawaii, has precluded attempts to resolve island uplift or subsidence.

A primary goal was to collect geochemical on a suite of submarine lavas to determine the origin of seamounts in the Galapagos and compared these to subaerial lava compositions to produce a new geochemical framework of mantle heterogeneity and plume theory in the Galapagos. Prior to this work no comprehensive sampling or analyses of any lavas erupted between the subaerial islands had been undertaken.  A wide range of geochemical data from 105 basalts erupted at 22 seamounts on the top of the platform and 25 basalts from two long lava flows at the leading edge of the Galapagos were collected. Our results show that the seamounts have chemistries representing the three most prominent geochemical endmembers of the Galápagos Array in isotopic space, but significantly less scatter in Pb isotopes compared to previous data. This suggests that variability in the Galápagos plume may be generated from a single differentiation event, where the observed linearity in Pb represents an isochron for the event (i.e., formation and recycling of a single slice of oceanic lithosphere). From this we modeled the evolution of the Galápagos as three stage melting and metasomatism from a single parent composition. We show for the first time that the geochemical diversity in the Galapagos can be formed from mixing of compositions resultant from the subduction and recycling of a single oceanic package at ~1.6 Ga, providing both a temporal and spatial constraint on the origin of the Galapagos. 

 

Another goal was to determine if terraces on the seamounts record periods of emergence related to subsidence or sea-level variations.  We use high-resolution bathymetric maps, visual observations, statistical analyses, and numerical models to investigate if seamounts record periods of past emergence, which may have provided land bridges between the larger islands.  From the new bathymetric data, we identified 79 erosional terraces on 30 seamounts that are presently at depths of 30 to 300 m, and observed erosional features (e.g., beach cobbles) on 22 seamounts with terraces. These exposure features proved valuable for constraining paleo-elevations and sea levels in the absence of more traditional markers (drowned coral reefs), which are absent in the Galápagos. Although intermittent subaerial connectivity between islands has been hypothesized, the depths of these erosional terraces are the first direct evidence of paleo-connectivity in the modern archipelago, which has implications for biodiversity and evolutionary models. Additionally, the terraces have non-randomly distributed depths, which likely represent long durations of exposure (i.e., sea-level still or lowstands). By comparing these peaks to those of subsidence adjusted sea-level curves, we identify the subsidence rate that best reproduces the observed terrace distributions (0.2–0.4 m/ka). Using these rates and evidence for erosional terraces at 300 m, we conclude that all islands in the central archipelago have been intermittently connected between 435 and 900 ka.

 

PRODUCTS: Four manuscripts have been published in peer-reviewed journals; including two graduate and one undergraduate student first authored manuscripts. Key results have been presented by four different lead authors at four conferences (AGU, Chapman Conference on Submarine Volcanism, IAVCEI and Goldschmidt). Nine abstracts have been presented international conferences.  Students have also presented results at three local conferences (Boise State Undergraduate Research Conference, Boise State Graduate Research Conference, and Society for Mining and Exploration). This project also produced 1 PhD Dissertation and 1 undergraduate senior thesis.

 

TRAINING: This project provided significant hands on training at both graduate and undergraduate level. In total, 5 undergraduates, two graduate students and one high school student were trained to collect or process data during this project. Many of these students presented outcomes of their research at conferences and were lead or co-authors on published manuscripts. 

 

OUTREACH: Volcano demonstrations and videos of the Galapagos dives were shown and discussed at the Annual Boise State STEM Exploration Day and Bronco Days (2016, 2017, 2018). Volcano demonstrations were brought to Elementary school stem nights (2016-2019). Video was also shown to the Boise State GeoClub in April 2017. Video, digital images and maps were provided to the Galapagos National Park and Charles Darwin Foundation to help with designations of the Galapagos Marine Sanctuary and for biological classifications.  A high-school student intern was trained to prepare samples for geochemical analyses.
